title: CLAUDE.md
text: C++ Core (src/extract_front_matter.cpp): Single-pass character scanning detects extracts front matter. Returns list found, fence_type, content, body. Handles format detection validation. R Wrapper (R/parse_front_matter.R): User-facing API calls C++ core, passes extracted content appropriate parser (YAML TOML).

title: CLAUDE.md
text: C++ code checks formats order (specific first): 1. PEP 723 (# /// script … # ///) - Python inline script metadata 2. Comment-wrapped YAML/TOML (# --- #' ---) 3. Standard YAML (---) TOML (+++)

text: R/parse_front_matter.R: Main API - parse_front_matter() read_front_matter() R/default_parsers.R: Default YAML (yaml12) TOML (tomledit) parsers src/extract_front_matter.cpp: C++ parsing logic extract_front_matter_cpp() entry point .claude/SPECIFICATION.md: Complete parsing specification edge cases

title: CLAUDE.md
text: complete parsing specification .claude/SPECIFICATION.md. Key rules: - Opening fence must document position 0 - Closing fence must exactly 3 characters (4+) - Invalid front matter returns NULL data original content body (errors) - comment-wrapped formats, closing fence must use prefix opening

title: Parse Front Matter from Documents
text: frontmatter extracts parses structured metadata (YAML TOML) beginning text documents. Front matter common pattern Quarto documents, R Markdown documents, static site generators, documentation systems, content management tools even Python R scripts metadata placed top document, separated main content delimiter fences.

title: Parse Front Matter from Documents
text: delimiter formats supported parsing available writing. Use shortcuts delimiter argument: "yaml" - Standard YAML (---) "toml" - Standard TOML (+++) "yaml_comment" / "toml_comment" - Comment-wrapped scripts (# --- / # +++) "yaml_roxy" / "toml_roxy" - Roxygen-style (#' --- / #' +++) "toml_pep723" - Python PEP 723 (# /// script) See parsing examples earlier README understand format looks like. ’s quick example TOML:
code:
# Use TOML format format_front_matter(doc, delimiter = "toml") #> [1] "+++
title = "Modified Title"
date = "2024-01-01"
tags = ["tutorial", "R"]
author = "New Author"
+++

Document content starts here.
"

code:
# Create a document with YAML front matter doc <- list(   data = list(title = "My Document", author = "Jane Doe"),   body = "Document content goes here." )  # Format as a string format_front_matter(doc) #> [1] "---
title: My Document
author: Jane Doe
---

Document content goes here.
"  # Write to a file tmp <- tempfile(fileext = ".md") write_front_matter(doc, tmp) readLines(tmp) #> [1] "---"                         "title: My Document"          #> [3] "author: Jane Doe"            "---"                         #> [5] ""                            "Document content goes here."  # Print to console (when path is NULL) write_front_matter(doc) #> --- #> title: My Document #> author: Jane Doe #> --- #>  #> Document content goes here.  # Use TOML format format_front_matter(doc, delimiter = "toml") #> [1] "+++
title = "My Document"
author = "Jane Doe"
+++

Document content goes here.
"  # Use comment-wrapped format for R scripts r_script <- list(   data = list(title = "Analysis Script"),   body = "# Load libraries
library(dplyr)" ) format_front_matter(r_script, delimiter = "yaml_comment") #> [1] "# ---
# title: Analysis Script
# ---
#
# Load libraries
library(dplyr)
"  # Roundtrip example: read, modify, write original <- "--- title: Original --- Content here"  doc <- parse_front_matter(original) doc$data$title <- "Modified" format_front_matter(doc) #> [1] "---
title: Modified
---

Content here
"

title: Parse YAML or TOML Front Matter — parse_front_matter
text: default YAML parser uses YAML 1.2 via yaml12::parse_yaml(). use YAML 1.1 parsing instead (via yaml::yaml.load()), set either: R option frontmatter.parse_yaml.spec "1.1" environment variable FRONTMATTER_PARSE_YAML_SPEC "1.1" option takes precedence environment variable. Valid values "1.1" "1.2" (default). YAML 1.1 differs YAML 1.2 several ways, notably handles boolean values (e.g., yes/booleans 1.1 strings 1.2).

title: Parse YAML or TOML Front Matter — parse_front_matter
code: # Parse YAML front matter text <- "--- title: My Document date: 2024-01-01 --- Document content here"  result <- parse_front_matter(text) result$data$title  # "My Document" #> [1] "My Document" result$body        # "Document content here" #> [1] "Document content here"  # Parse TOML front matter text <- "+++ title = 'My Document' date = 2024-01-01 +++ Document content"  result <- parse_front_matter(text)  # Get raw YAML without parsing result <- parse_front_matter(text, parse_yaml = identity)  # Use a custom parser that adds metadata result <- parse_front_matter(   text,   parse_yaml = function(x) {     data <- yaml12::parse_yaml(x)     data$parsed_at <- Sys.time()     data   } )  # Or read from a file tmpfile <- tempfile(fileext = ".md") writeLines(text, tmpfile)  read_front_matter(tmpfile) #> <front_matter format="toml", delimiter="toml"> #> ──── $data ──── #> $title #> [1] "My Document" #>  #> $date #> [1] "2024-01-01" #>  #>  #> ──── $body ──── #> Document content

title: frontmatter (development version)
text: New format_front_matter() write_front_matter() functions serializing documents YAML TOML front matter. inverse parse_front_matter() read_front_matter(), enabling full roundtrip support. Supports delimiter formats including standard (---, +++), comment-wrapped (# ---, #' ---), PEP 723. Note roundtrip perfect; comments formatting within front matter content may preserved. parse_front_matter() read_front_matter() now attach format fence_type attributes returned list, making easier preserve original format rewriting documents. Fixed issue parsing front matter comment-prefixed formats (e.g., R Python files) body content preserved correctly. body now retained -, stripping leading comment-prefixed empty lines.

title: frontmatter 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2026-01-14 Initial CRAN release. Extract parse YAML TOML front matter text documents read_front_matter() parse_front_matter(). Support multiple front matter formats: Standard YAML (--- delimiters) TOML (+++ delimiters) Comment-wrapped formats R Python files (# #' prefixes) PEP 723 Python inline script metadata Fast C++ parsing graceful handling incomplete front matter. Flexible parser integration: default uses yaml12::parse_yaml() tomledit::parse_toml() can provide custom parsers.
